facts.text: General election held on March 11, 1972, for Nuh constituency to Haryana Legislative Assembly. Appellant (Rahim Khan), Independent candidate, declared elected by plurality of less than 2,000 votes over first respondent (Khurshid Ahmed), Indian National Congress candidate.
Appellant previously elected from same constituency in 1967 as Deputy Minister; first respondent elected in 1968 bye-election and became Cabinet Minister.

First respondent filed Election Petition No. 7 of 1972 challenging appellant's election on grounds of corrupt practices including bribery, undue influence, appeal to religion and caste, and publication of false statements.

Punjab and Haryana High Court by judgment dated March 12, 1973, set aside appellant's election finding corrupt practices under Sections 123(1), (2), (3), (4) of Representation of People Act, 1951: bribery via car to Respondent No. 3 (Sohanlal), distribution of handbill Ex. P.W.4/3 appealing to religion, undue influence, and false statements.

Handbill Ex. P.W.4/3 existed before March 12, 1972; appellant supplied copies to agents for distribution among Muslim voters; appeals made on March 9-10, 1972, in villages Notki Gohana, Khedli Nuh, Mewli, Malab, Nagina, Karherrha, Pinangwan, Bhadas, Gliagas accusing first respondent of violating Islamic tenets, eating pork, forcing Muslims to eat pork, being a kafir.
On February 14, 1972, appellant placed car No. DLF 675 at disposal of Respondent No. 3 (Sohanlal) with promise to meet hire and running expenses.
Nuh constituency has preponderant Muslim (Meo) voting strength; both candidates Muslims; Harijans traditionally vote Congress unless lured.
Ex. P.18 application to Deputy Commissioner with handbills submitted March 10, 1972; Ex. P.19 to Chief Electoral Officer posted March 10, received March 13.
Section 144 Cr.P.C. order prohibiting public meetings of five or more in constituency; s.126 RPA prohibited meetings within 48 hours of poll.
Appellant denied knowledge of handbill; claimed statements false; no belief in their truth.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellant committed corrupt practice under s.123(1) RPA by providing car and expenses to Respondent No.3 to induce continuance as candidate.
Whether distribution of handbill Ex.P.W.4/3 by appellant or agents constituted corrupt practices under s.123(2) undue influence, s.123(3) appeal on ground of religion, s.123(4) false statements.
Appellate perspective: limitations on re-appraisal of evidence; when High Court findings of fact can be disturbed.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant committed bribery u/s 123(1) by providing Rs.1000 and car DLF 675 to Sohanlal (R3) on Feb 14 to prevent withdrawal and attract Harijan votes.

Appellant and agents distributed handbill Ex.PW4/3 on March 9-10 in multiple villages appealing to Muslims to vote for appellant as true Muslim and against petitioner as kafir who eats pork, forces pork on Muslims; speeches by appellant and Tayyab Hussain.

respondent_arguments.text: No proof car provided to induce non-withdrawal; mere aid to fellow candidate not corrupt practice unless to induce withdrawal.
Handbills fabricated post-election; no nexus to appellant; witnesses partisan turncoats; s.144 CrPC prohibited meetings; official documents antedated.
High Court erred in relying on defector witnesses; oral evidence unsafe without documents.

court_reasoning.text: Bribery charge not proved; car provision not linked to inducement not to withdraw; insufficient reliable evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Key is whether aid to induce non-withdrawal; unproven.

court_reasoning.text: Handbills Ex.PW4/3 existed pre-poll (Ex.P18, P19 genuine); nexus to appellant via motive, prior circulation; distributed in villages; constitutes appeal to religion u/s123(3) and false statements u/s123(4); no undue influence u/s123(2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Eating pork as appeal to religion given popular sentiment; false statements admitted untrue.

court_reasoning.text: Appellate court can re-appraise evidence but slow to disturb trial court findings unless perverse; heavy burden on challenger; quasi-criminal standard.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Strict proof needed for corrupt practices.

holdings.text: No corrupt practice u/s123(1); overturns High Court on bribery.
Corrupt practices u/s123(3) appeal to religion and s.123(4) false statements proved via handbill distribution; election void.

precedents_cited.relevance: Appellate power under s.116A; limitations on reversing trial court findings.
Setting aside trial court fact findings only if unsound/perverse.
Purpose of election law to safeguard purity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ambika Saran Singh v. Mahant Mahadev Nand Giri
precedents_cited.relevance: View partisan evidence with circumspection but not dismiss outright; particulars in election petitions.

precedents_cited.case_name: B. Rajagopala Rao v. N. G. Ranga
precedents_cited.relevance: Caution on enemies printing notices post-election.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Appeal under 116A; corrupt practices defined in 123; naming guilty under 99; no public meetings under 126.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Endorsements on documents; opinion on handwriting.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court order upheld in part; appellant's election from Nuh constituency void due to corrupt practices under s.123(3) and (4) RPA via distribution of handbill Ex.PW4/3; bribery finding reversed but sufficient grounds exist to void election.

key_quotes.text: The campaign pollutants must be kept down at the polls if electoral disenchantment is not to grip the general community. The Court, in this regard, is the sentinel on the qui vive.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Role of court in maintaining electoral purity.

key_quotes.text: Elections are the cornerstone of the parliamentary system and the arm of the law should not hang limp in the face of open contravention.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Importance of strict enforcement against corrupt practices.

key_quotes.text: In the ultimate analysis we hold that the appellant did get the handbills... printed and distributed... Thereby he made statements which were untrue... constitutes an appeal to religion... a contravention under s.123... unseating... inevitable.
key_quotes.speaker: court
